questions.title: Missing Null Terminator
questions.description: What happens when this code runs?
options: Prints ABC followed by garbage characters
questions.explanation: The array has no null terminator. When printf tries to print it as a string (%s), it will continue reading past the array until it finds a '\0', potentially printing garbage. Fix: Use char str[4] = {'A', 'B', 'C', '\0'}; or char str[] = "ABC";
hints: Strings in C must end with '\0'
The array has no null terminator

questions.title: String Length vs Size
questions.explanation: strlen(str) counts characters until '\0', giving 5. sizeof(str) gives the total array size including the null terminator, giving 6. Remember: sizeof includes the '\0', strlen doesn't count it.
hints: sizeof counts total bytes in the array

questions.title: Buffer Overflow
questions.description: What is the problem with this code?
options: Buffer overflow - copying 14 bytes into 5-byte buffer
dest needs to be initialized first
questions.explanation: strcpy copies 14 characters (13 + null terminator) into a 5-byte buffer, causing a buffer overflow. This is dangerous and can crash the program or create security vulnerabilities. Fix: Use strncpy or make dest larger.
hints: How many bytes does src need?

questions.title: String Initialization
questions.description: Which creates a valid null-terminated string?
questions.explanation: Option B automatically allocates 6 bytes and adds '\0'. Option C explicitly allocates 6 bytes for the 5 characters plus '\0'. Option A is missing the null terminator and will cause issues.
hints: Option A has no null terminator

questions.title: Character Array Equality
questions.explanation: Both str1 and str2 are initialized with the same content. str1[0] and str2[0] both contain 'A', so the comparison is true, printing 1.
hints: The comparison checks if they're equal

questions.title: String Concatenation Bug
questions.description: What is wrong with this concatenation?
questions.explanation: "Hello" is 6 bytes, "World" is 6 bytes, so "HelloWorld" needs 11 bytes total. But str1 is only 10 bytes, causing a buffer overflow by 1 byte. Fix: Make str1 larger, e.g., char str1[20].
hints: str1 needs to fit both strings

questions.title: String Comparison
questions.description: What are the two outputs of this program?
questions.explanation: First: str1 == str2 compares pointer addresses (which are different), so it prints 0 (false). Second: strcmp compares string contents, which are equal, so it returns 0 (strings are equal).
hints: strcmp returns 0 when strings are equal

questions.title: Safe String Copy
questions.description: Which is the SAFEST way to copy a string with size limit?
questions.explanation: strncpy with size limit and manual null termination is the safest. It prevents buffer overflow and ensures null termination. strcpy has no bounds checking, memcpy doesn't add '\0', and assignment doesn't copy content.
hints: Reserve one byte for null terminator

questions.title: Modifying String Literal
questions.explanation: Attempting to modify a string literal is undefined behavior. String literals are typically stored in read-only memory. Fix: Use char str[] = "Hello"; instead of char* str = "Hello";
hints: Use char[] to get a modifiable copy

questions.title: Empty String
questions.explanation: An empty string "" contains only the null terminator '\0'. strlen counts characters before '\0', so it returns 0.
hints: An empty string has no visible characters
It only contains the null terminator

questions.title: Hidden Null
questions.explanation: The string literal "abcd" includes a null terminator. With size 5, str[4] is '\0', which prints as 0 with %d.

questions.title: Embedded Null
questions.explanation: printf with %s stops at the first '\0'. The embedded null ends the string, so it prints only 'a'.
hints: %s prints until the first null terminator

questions.title: strncmp Result
questions.explanation: strncmp compares only the first 2 characters. "ca" == "ca", so it returns 0.
hints: Only the first 2 chars are compared

questions.title: fgets Newline
questions.description: What does this program do if the user types: hi and presses Enter?
questions.explanation: fgets keeps the newline if there's room. The buffer contains "hi\n\0", so printf prints the newline too.
hints: fgets includes the newline when possible

questions.title: Size of Array vs Pointer
questions.description: What does this program print on a 64-bit system?
questions.explanation: sizeof(str) is the array size including '\0' (6). sizeof(p) is the size of a pointer on 64-bit (8).

questions.title: String Literal
questions.description: What is the length of this string?
questions.explanation: strlen counts characters before null terminator. "Hello" has 5 characters.

questions.title: String Comparison
questions.explanation: == compares pointers, not contents. Compiler may optimize identical literals to same address.

questions.title: String Copy
questions.explanation: dest is uninitialized pointer. strcpy writes to random address. Need to allocate memory first.

questions.title: String Concatenation
questions.explanation: strcat appends s2 to s1. s1 becomes "Hello World".

questions.title: String Literal Modification
questions.explanation: String literals are typically in read-only memory. Modifying causes undefined behavior.

questions.title: scanf Return Value
options: The sum of x and y
questions.explanation: scanf returns the number of successfully read items. Here 2 integers were read, so it returns 2.
hints: scanf returns number of items read

questions.title: scanf Format Width
questions.explanation: The format %5s reads maximum 5 characters. scanf reads "Hello" from "HelloWorld".

questions.title: printf Width and Precision
questions.explanation: %5.2f means minimum 5 chars width, 2 decimal places. "3.14" is 4 chars, padded with 1 space: " 3.14".

questions.title: Array Initialization
questions.explanation: Partial initialization zeros remaining elements. arr[2] and arr[4] are 0.

questions.title: strcmp Comparison
questions.explanation: strcmp returns 0 when strings are equal. 0 == 0 is true (1).

questions.title: strcmp Return Value
questions.description: What does strcmp return for these strings?
questions.explanation: strcmp returns negative when first string is less. "abc" < "xyz", so result < 0 is true (1).

questions.title: strcpy Usage
questions.explanation: strcpy copies the string including null terminator. dest becomes "hello".

questions.title: strcat Concatenation
questions.explanation: strcat appends the second string to the first. Result is "Hello World".

questions.title: Character Classification
questions.explanation: isupper returns non-zero for uppercase letters. 'A' is uppercase.

questions.title: strlen Result
questions.explanation: The string "C" has length 1 (excluding the null terminator).

questions.title: String Literal Size
questions.explanation: String literals include the null terminator, so "hi" has size 3.

questions.title: strncpy Behavior
questions.description: What is the issue with this code?
questions.explanation: strncpy does not guarantee a null terminator if the source is longer than the buffer.

questions.title: strcmp Result
questions.description: What does strcmp return when strings are equal?
questions.code_template: strcmp("abc", "abc");
questions.explanation: strcmp returns 0 when strings are equal.

questions.title: strcat Destination Size
questions.description: What is required for this code to be safe?
options: dest must be at least 7 bytes
dest must be at least 8 bytes
dest must be at least 9 bytes
dest must be at least 10 bytes
questions.explanation: "Hi" has length 2 and "There" has length 5, so total is 7 plus one null terminator = 8 bytes.

questions.title: toupper Result
questions.explanation: toupper converts lowercase to uppercase. 'b' becomes 'B'.

questions.title: strchr Result
questions.description: What does strchr return when the character is found?
questions.code_template: char *p = strchr("hello", 'l');
questions.explanation: strchr returns a pointer to the first occurrence of the character.

questions.title: snprintf Size
questions.explanation: snprintf returns the full length (5) and writes up to 3 chars plus null, so buf is "hel".

questions.title: fgets Buffer Limit
questions.description: How many characters can fgets store here (excluding null terminator)?
questions.code_template:
char buf[8];
fgets(buf, sizeof(buf), stdin);
questions.explanation: fgets reads at most size-1 characters and adds a null terminator.

questions.title: strcmp Ordering
questions.code_template: strcmp("cat", "dog");
questions.explanation: "cat" comes before "dog", so strcmp returns a negative value.

questions.title: strncat Size
questions.description: Which is required to safely use strncat?
questions.code_template:
char dest[6] = "hi";
strncat(dest, "abc", 3);
options: dest must be at least 4 bytes
dest must be at least 5 bytes
dest must be at least 6 bytes
questions.explanation: "hi" (2 chars) + "abc" (3 chars) + '\0' requires 6 bytes.

questions.title: Basic strlen Usage
questions.explanation: strlen() returns the number of characters in the string excluding the null terminator. 'Hello' has 5 characters, so strlen(str) returns 5.
hints: strlen counts characters until the null terminator
The null terminator is not counted

questions.title: strcpy Buffer Copy
questions.explanation: strcpy() copies the string from src to dest including the null terminator. Since dest has enough space (10 bytes) to hold 'World' (6 bytes including null terminator), it prints 'World'.
hints: strcpy copies the entire string including null terminator
Check if dest has enough space
src is 6 bytes including the null terminator

questions.title: strncpy Padding Behavior
questions.explanation: strncpy() copies up to n characters. If the source is shorter than n, it pads the remaining space with null bytes. Here, 'Hi' (2 chars + 1 null = 3 bytes) is copied, then strncpy pads with 2 more null bytes to reach 5 total. The remaining 'XXXXX' stays. However, the string prints as 'Hi' because printf stops at the first null terminator.
hints: strncpy pads with null bytes if src is shorter than n
strncpy may not null-terminate if src is longer than n
printf stops at the first null terminator

questions.title: strcat Basic Concatenation
questions.explanation: strcat() appends the string src to the end of dest. It finds the null terminator in dest and starts copying src from that position. The result is 'Hello World'.
hints: It appends src to the end of dest
The original content of dest is preserved

questions.title: strncat Length Limit
questions.explanation: strncat() appends at most n characters from src to dest. Here it appends 3 characters ('1', '2', '3') to 'Test', resulting in 'Test123'. Unlike strncpy, strncat always null-terminates the result.
hints: strncat appends at most n characters
strncat always adds a null terminator
Count how many characters are appended

questions.title: strcmp Equality Check
questions.explanation: strcmp() compares two strings lexicographically. It returns 0 if the strings are identical. Since both str1 and str2 contain 'apple', strcmp returns 0 and 'Equal' is printed.
hints: strcmp returns 0 when strings are equal
strcmp compares strings character by character

questions.title: strcmp Lexicographic Order
questions.explanation: strcmp() returns a positive value if str1 is lexicographically greater than str2. Since 'b' (in 'banana') comes after 'a' (in 'apple') in ASCII order, strcmp returns a positive value and 'Greater' is printed.
hints: strcmp returns positive if str1 > str2

questions.title: strncmp Partial Comparison
questions.explanation: strncmp() compares at most the first n characters of two strings. Here it compares the first 7 characters. Both strings have 'testing' (7 characters) in common, so strncmp returns 0 and 'Match' is printed.
hints: strncmp compares only the first n characters
Count the first 7 characters of each string
The digits are beyond the 7th position

questions.title: strcasecmp Case Insensitive
questions.description: What does this program print? (Assume strcasecmp is available)
questions.explanation: strcasecmp() performs a case-insensitive comparison. It treats 'Hello' and 'HELLO' as the same string, returning 0. Therefore, 'Same' is printed. Note that strcasecmp is in <strings.h>, not <string.h>.

questions.title: strchr Find Character
questions.explanation: strchr() returns a pointer to the first occurrence of the character 'o' in the string. The first 'o' is at index 4 in 'Hello World'. Printing from that pointer prints 'o World'.
hints: strchr returns a pointer to the first occurrence
It returns a pointer, not just the character

questions.title: strrchr Last Occurrence
questions.explanation: strrchr() returns a pointer to the last occurrence of 'g' in the string. In 'programming', the last 'g' is at index 10. ptr - str gives the offset from the start of the string, which is 10.
hints: Count from the beginning to find the index

questions.title: strstr Substring Search
questions.explanation: strstr() returns a pointer to the first occurrence of the substring 'quick' in str. It finds 'quick' starting at index 4 and returns a pointer to that position. Printing from that pointer prints 'quick brown fox'.
hints: strstr finds the first occurrence of a substring
It returns a pointer to where the substring starts
What comes after 'quick' in the string?

questions.title: strstr Not Found
questions.explanation: strstr() returns NULL if the substring is not found in the string. Since 'world' is not present in 'Hello', strstr returns NULL and 'Not found' is printed.
hints: strstr returns NULL if substring is not found

questions.title: strtok Basic Tokenization
questions.explanation: strtok() breaks a string into tokens based on delimiters. The first call returns a pointer to the first token 'one'. It replaces the delimiter ',' with a null terminator internally.
hints: strtok splits the string by delimiters
The first call returns the first token

questions.title: strtok Multiple Calls
questions.explanation: The first strtok call returns 'red'. Subsequent calls with NULL as the first argument continue tokenizing the same string. The second call returns 'green'.
hints: strtok(NULL, delim) continues from where it left off
The second call returns the next token

questions.title: strtok Modifies String
questions.explanation: strtok() modifies the original string by replacing delimiters with null terminators. After the first call, the first '-' is replaced with '\0', so printing str prints only 'a' (up to the null terminator).
hints: It replaces delimiters with null terminators
printf stops at the first null terminator

questions.title: sprintf Basic Formatting
questions.explanation: sprintf() formats and stores a string in a buffer instead of printing to stdout. It works like printf but writes to the buffer. Here it formats 'The answer is 42' into the buffer.
hints: sprintf writes formatted output to a string
It works like printf but to a buffer
%d is replaced with the value of num

questions.title: snprintf Buffer Safety
questions.explanation: snprintf() writes at most n-1 characters to the buffer (leaving room for null terminator). With a 10-byte buffer, it writes 'Hello Wor' (9 chars + null). However, it returns 12, the length of the string that would have been written if the buffer were large enough.
hints: snprintf truncates output to fit the buffer
It returns the length that would have been written
The buffer can hold 9 characters plus null terminator

questions.title: String Literal vs Array
questions.description: What is the difference between these declarations?
options: str1 can be modified, str2 cannot
str2 can be modified, str1 cannot
questions.explanation: str1 is a pointer to a string literal stored in read-only memory and should not be modified (undefined behavior). str2 is a character array initialized with a copy of the string, stored on the stack, and can be modified.
hints: String literals are stored in read-only memory
Arrays store their own copy of data
Modifying string literals is undefined behavior

questions.title: String Literal Modification
questions.description: What happens when this program runs?
questions.explanation: String literals are stored in read-only memory. Attempting to modify a string literal through a pointer results in undefined behavior, which may cause a segmentation fault or other runtime errors.
hints: Modifying read-only memory is undefined behavior

questions.title: Buffer Overflow Detection
questions.description: What is the problem with this code?
questions.explanation: The buffer has space for 5 characters, but 'Hello' requires 6 bytes (5 characters + null terminator). strcpy will write beyond the buffer boundaries, causing a buffer overflow and undefined behavior.
hints: Count the bytes needed including null terminator
Writing beyond buffer boundaries is dangerous

questions.title: Array Bounds Safety
questions.explanation: sizeof() returns the total size of the array in bytes, not the string length. The array is declared with size 6, so sizeof(str) returns 6, regardless of the content.
hints: sizeof returns the size of the array, not string length
The array size is specified as 6

questions.title: strlen vs sizeof
questions.explanation: strlen() returns the number of characters before the null terminator (4 for 'Test'). sizeof() returns the total allocated size of the array (10 bytes).
hints: strlen counts characters until null terminator

questions.title: strncpy No Null Terminator
questions.description: What is the potential issue with this code?
questions.explanation: strncpy copies exactly 5 bytes from src to dest. Since 'Hello' is 5 characters, there's no room for the null terminator in the 5 bytes copied. dest is not null-terminated, causing undefined behavior when printf tries to print it.
hints: src has exactly 5 characters plus null terminator

questions.title: strtok Edge Case
questions.explanation: strtok() treats consecutive delimiters as a single delimiter and skips them. It only returns non-empty tokens. Leading and trailing delimiters are also ignored. So it prints 'a b'.
hints: Consecutive delimiters are treated as one

questions.title: sprintf Return Value
questions.explanation: sprintf() returns the number of characters written to the buffer (excluding the null terminator). 'Count: 123' has 10 characters, so sprintf returns 10.
hints: sprintf returns the number of characters written
The null terminator is not counted

questions.title: strchr Null Character
questions.explanation: strchr() can find the null terminator. Every C string ends with '\0', so strchr(str, '\0') returns a pointer to the null terminator, not NULL. Therefore, 'Found' is printed.
hints: strchr can search for the null terminator
It returns a pointer to the terminator, not NULL

questions.title: strcat Buffer Overflow Risk
questions.description: What is wrong with this code?
questions.explanation: dest has 10 bytes. 'Hello' takes 6 bytes (including null). ' World' takes 7 bytes (including null). Together they need 12 bytes (5+6+1), exceeding the 10-byte buffer. strcat causes a buffer overflow.
hints: Count total bytes needed including null terminator

questions.title: strncat Safe Concatenation
questions.explanation: dest has 10 bytes, 'Hi' uses 3 (including null). Remaining space is 7 bytes. We calculate sizeof(dest) - strlen(dest) - 1 = 10 - 2 - 1 = 7. strncat appends at most 7 chars, but always null-terminates. So it appends 'Hi' + '123456' (6 chars) to fit in 9 total + null.
hints: Account for existing content and null byte

questions.title: strcmp vs strncmp
questions.explanation: strcmp compares the entire strings and finds them different ('test' vs 'testing'), returning non-zero (r1 == 0 is false, prints 0). strncmp compares only the first 4 characters ('test' vs 'test'), which match, returning 0 (r2 == 0 is true, prints 1).
